summary: This is a DOJ OIG interview transcript of a BOP employee, Jermaine, who was the Captain at MCC New York during Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration. The interview focuses on the circumstances surrounding Epstein's death, including staffing, protocols, cell assignments, and potential failures in supervision and counts. The witness discusses his interactions with Epstein, the vetting of cell mates, the removal of Epstein's cell mate on August 9, 2019, and systemic issues within the SHU.

persons.name: Jermaine
persons.role: BOP Discipline Hearing Officer (formerly Captain at MCC)
persons.context: The interviewee, a BOP employee who was the Captain at MCC during Epstein's incarceration. He discusses his responsibilities, interactions with Epstein, and the events leading up to Epstein's death.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The high-profile inmate who died in his cell at MCC on August 10, 2019. The interview extensively covers his housing, behavior, and the circumstances of his death.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: Epstein's former cell mate, a former police officer convicted of murder. Epstein claimed Tartaglione tried to kill him in July 2019, which was investigated and deemed not credible.

persons.name: Efrain Reyes
persons.context: The inmate vetted and selected to be Epstein's cell mate after the Tartaglione incident. He was released from court on August 9, 2019, leaving Epstein without a cell mate.

persons.name: Warden N'Diaye
persons.context: The Warden at MCC who gave directives regarding Epstein's management, including the requirement for a cell mate and the vetting process.

persons.name: Associate Warden Adge
persons.context: The AW over Custody at MCC. The witness discusses reporting lines and her being on annual leave during the incident.

persons.name: Lieutenant
persons.context: The appointed SHU Lieutenant at MCC. The witness states he specifically directed him to ensure Epstein had a cell mate at all times.

persons.name: Lieutenant
persons.context: The Operations Lieutenant on duty the morning Epstein was found. He called the witness to report the incident.

persons.name: Lieutenant
persons.context: A Lieutenant who worked morning watch on August 10, 2019. The witness discusses her failure to conduct proper rounds and discrepancies in her log.

persons.name: Tova Noel
persons.context: A Correctional Officer assigned to the SHU on the morning of August 10, 2019. She and Michael Thomas were the staff on duty when Epstein was found.

persons.name: Michael Thomas
persons.context: A non-custody staff member (Material Handler) working overtime in the SHU on the morning of August 10, 2019. He entered Epstein's cell without supervision.

persons.name: Unit Manager
persons.context: The Unit Manager who was escorting Epstein from attorney visitation on the evening of August 9, 2019. The witness authorized him to allow Epstein a phone call.

persons.name: Joaquin Guzman
persons.context: Mentioned as an example of a high-profile inmate housed in the Ten South Special Management Unit at MCC.

persons.name: Nathaniel
persons.context: The Institution Duty Officer the witness attempted to call on the morning of August 10, 2019, after being notified of Epstein's death.

connections.description: Jermaine, as Captain, was responsible for Epstein's security and supervision. He interacted with Epstein approximately three times and authorized a phone call for him on August 9.
Epstein and Tartaglione were cell mates. Epstein claimed Tartaglione tried to kill him on July 23, 2019, an allegation that was investigated and deemed not credible.
Reyes was vetted and selected to be Epstein's cell mate after the Tartaglione incident. He was released from court on August 9, 2019, leaving Epstein alone in his cell.
Jermaine reported directly to Warden N'Diaye and received directives from him regarding Epstein's management, including the cell mate requirement.
Jermaine, as Captain, was the direct supervisor of Lieutenant , the SHU Lieutenant. He specifically directed him to ensure Epstein had a cell mate.
Noel and Thomas were the two staff members assigned to the SHU on the morning watch shift of August 10, 2019, when Epstein was found deceased.
Jermaine's normal chain of command included reporting to AW Adge, though he also took direction directly from the Warden.

events.title: Epstein found unresponsive with fabric
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive on the floor of his cell with a homemade piece of fabric on his chest. His cell mate, Nicholas Tartaglione, alerted staff. Epstein claimed Tartaglione tried to kill him, but an investigation found the claim not credible.

events.title: Efrain Reyes released from court
events.description: Inmate Efrain Reyes, Epstein's cell mate, went to court and was released, not returning to MCC. Staff in the SHU were allegedly notified at 1:50 PM but failed to report that Epstein was now without a cell mate.

events.title: Epstein's last phone call
events.description: On the evening of August 9, Epstein asked Captain Jermaine for a phone call. Jermaine authorized Unit Manager to monitor an unrecorded call, instructing him to log it. It is believed Epstein called his mother.

events.title: Epstein found deceased
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at approximately 6:30 AM by staff. He was pronounced dead. The staff on duty (Noel and Thomas) had not conducted proper counts or rounds.

events.title: Missing inmate file
events.description: After Epstein's death, Captain Jermaine went to secure Epstein's SHU inmate file and found it essentially empty, missing standard documents like 292s and intake screenings. He believes documents were removed.

events.title: OIG Interview of Jermaine
events.description: The DOJ Office of the Inspector General conducts a voluntary, sworn interview with BOP employee Jermaine at FCI Fort Dix as part of its investigation into Epstein's death.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), 150 Park Row, New York, NY
Ten South (Special Management Unit) at MCC
West Side Administrative Building, FCI Fort Dix, New Jersey
Federal Law Enforcement Training Center, Glynco, Georgia
keyFacts: Epstein was not in his assigned cell for six days prior to his death due to staff failing to update Sentry paperwork after cell rotations.
Epstein's SHU inmate file was found empty after his death, leading the witness to believe documents had been removed.
Multiple required counts (4:00 PM, 10:00 PM, 12:00 AM, 3:00 AM, 5:00 AM) on August 9-10, 2019, were not conducted, and count slips were falsified.

The witness states that if he had been notified Epstein's cell mate was not returning on August 9, he would have immediately worked to assign a new cell mate or place Epstein under direct observation.
The witness reviewed video footage after the incident and saw SHU staff sleeping on duty and not conducting required rounds.
